chapter.title: What are neural tube defects?
chapter.para: Neural tube defects (NTDs) are amongst the most common birth defects. The prevalence has dropped in the UK from around 4.5 per 1000 live births to less than 1 per 1000 live births. This is attributed to a combination of screening and preconception folate supplementation.

NTD is a broad term encompassing a heterogeneous group of congenital spinal anomalies that result from defective closure of the neural tube early in foetal life. The upper and lower ends of the neural tube close last and these tend to be common sites of the anomalies. There are 2 broad categories: open lesions when the skin fails to close in the midline, and closed where there is skin coverage. The presentation varies with both the site and the extent of the lesion.

listitem.para: These describe lesions when there has been failure to close the neural tube (either brain or spinal cord) leading to herniation of neural tissue through a bony and skin defect where there has also been a failure of midline fusion in utero.

row.entry: Malformation
Clinical course
Anencephaly: Forebrain fails to form
A lethal condition. Any infants born alive do not survive beyond a few hours.
Encephalocele: Herniation of meninges and brain
If there is significant brain herniation then infants will die in the new born period.

Spina bifida manifesta Meninges ± spinal cord protruding through a defect in the posterior spine (meningocele/ myelomeningocele). This is an example of open spinal dysraphism as vertebra and failed to close.
The spinal cord defect will require surgical closure at birth and there will be long-term neurological deficits
Malformation
Clinical course
Spina bifida occulta : Failure of spinal arch to close

These can be seen clinically by a tuft of hair, or deviated natal cleft. The incidence of spina bifida occulta is high (~10% of the population) and most are asymptomatic and incidentally recognized on routine radiography.
Lipomeningocele: A meningocele with an associated fatty mass
This is presents sent as fatty mass over the spine – requires imaging to clarify if dysraphism or cord involvement.

This presents during childhood due to thethering of the cord with problems with leg movement, bladder and bowel control, lower back pain and spinal deformity. The presentation may be delayed until adulthood. It is important to diagnose and intervene as early as possible to minimize functional loss.
A pit at the base of spine, for which the base cannot be seen. If missed on neonatal examination it presents as meningitis in infancy.

chapter.title: Life story – antenatal
chapter.para: Fiona is a 28 year old young woman in her first pregnancy. Although this was unplanned she is delighted with the news and attends for routine antenatal screening which shows that there are signs of spina bifida. You have been asked to meet her and she has written down the questions she would most like to ask you.

callout.bridgehead: How do you know and are you sure?
callout.para: All pregnancies in the UK are offered the ‘triple test’, which is a blood test for alpha fetoprotein (AFP), beta human chorionic gonadotrophin and oestriol. Many places add in a nuchal translucency test which helps to identify foetus’s with Downs syndrome and thus becomes a quadruple test. A raised AFP can be associated with incomplete closure of the spinal canal. In addition all women have an antenatal ultrasound. Together, these tests offer a 70% sensitivity marker of Down’s syndrome, Edwards Syndrome and Patau’s syndrome. Foetal ultrasonography looks particularly at the development of the spinal cord and canal, which in the hands of an expert radiographer will demonstrate the lesion which can then be confirmed non-invasively with a foetal MRI scan. Some babies may be offered antenatal surgery to close the neural tube defect and the evidence suggests that this decreases the likelihood of developing hydrocephalus.

callout.bridgehead: Why has this happened and will it happen again?
callout.para: Factors associated with spina bifida include:

listitem.para: Spina bifida is more common among Hispanic and white people of Northern European descent. Genetic studies have identified 42 candidate genes and more are likely to be found as technology advances.
Folic acid deficiency – taking folate supplements decreases the risk of spina bifida.
Diabetes – particularly if poor control of diabetes in early pregnancy.
Maternal obesity.

Medications – in particular sodium valproate (Epilim) increases the risk of spina bifida by around 4-5 times. Young women should not be treated with sodium valproate for epilepsy unless all other treatments have been tried. The advice is that if on sodium valproate they should also be using contraception and they are aware of the risk birth malformation in particular spina bifida and cleft palate. To ensure women are aware there is now a pregnancy prevention programme for women on valproate and they need to sign a form on an annual basis to make sure clinical teams have counselled them.

Family history – Couples who have had one child with a neural tube defect have a slightly higher chance of having another baby with the same defect. That risk increases if two previous children have been affected by the condition. In addition, a woman who was born with a neural tube defect, or who has a close relative with one, has a greater chance of giving birth to a child with spina bifida.

All women should take folate (400mcg) if planning a pregnancy, and for the first 12 weeks of pregnancy. If they or a close family member has previously had an affected child in the family then they should take a high dose folate supplement of 4mg again for one to three months prior to conception and for the first three months of pregnancy.
If diabetic optimise diabetic control prior to conception.
If on sodium valproate young women should be changed to a suitable alternative anti epileptic in consultation with the team managing their epilepsy prior to planning a pregnancy

callout.bridgehead: What will it mean for my child and us as a family?

para.emphasis: Will my baby survive the pregnancy and delivery?

listitem.para: Almost certainly your baby will be born alive. It can be helpful to see pictures of babies with previous lesions in order to prepare themselves for delivery. It is also important to explain that this is an issue about the way the spinal cord was formed and hat whilst the baby will have specific needs that will have to be promptly addressed after birth they are not otherwise ill or fragile.

para.emphasis: What will happen after my baby is born?

listitem.para: When the baby is born there will be a lot of people in the room to make sure the baby is immediately appropriately cared for. That the baby will need to go to special care baby unit and if this is an open lesion will require immediate surgery. Some babies may develop hydrocephalus, or increased fluid in the central spaces within the brain that may also require treatment with a tube or shunt. We will also need to help you baby empty their bladder by putting a tube into their bladder. It is helpful for parents to have a leaflet about the neonatal unit so they know what this will look like and what to expect.

para.emphasis: In what ways will I have to adapt my parenting to meet my child needs?

listitem.para: You will be helped to learn skills to keep your child well which will include learning to use a catheter to empty their bladder, signs to look out for suggesting problems with their shunt and techniques to help with their mobility. There are ways for an older child to be socially continent and ways to optimise their independent mobility.

para.emphasis: Will one of us have to stop working to meet our child’s needs?

listitem.para: All babies need a lot of care and your baby is no different, but the way you care for them may be different; you may need to learn to catheterise rather than change a nappy. Therapy and nursing staff will be happy to teach these skills to anyone caring for your child, so it should be possible to keep working.

para.emphasis: Will my child have a happy life?

listitem.para: Most children lead very happy and fulfilled lives, and lots live independently as adults. Shine is a charity that supports people with spina bifida and their families. They have an excellent website that will help you to see how people have lived inspiring lives.

para.emphasis: Will my child be able to talk? How will it affect their learning?

listitem.para: Most children with spina bifida and/or hydrocephalus are able communicators, have intellectual abilities within the typical range for their age and will go to mainstream schools. Some children with spina bifida and/or hydrocephalus will have learning difficulties, some of whom will go to more specialist schools, depending on their individual needs and choices. With appropriate support, based on assessment of individual needs, all children with spina bifida and/or hydrocephalus should be able to participate in most activities and enjoy good quality of life.

para.emphasis: Will it affect the length of my child’s life?

listitem.para: Most children with spina bifida will have medical issues and it is important that these are managed well as they impact on both the quality of the child’s life and also its length. There are also other medical issues that can crop up, such as hip problems, but these are not because parents have missed caring in an appropriate way. In recent years, with improved understanding of long term needs and the importance of specialist follow-up into adulthood, instances have greatly reduced of secondary issues such as renal impairment which used to be seen in adults with spina bifida. This has been associated with an increase in lifespan.

chapter.title: Medical issues associated with spina bifida

callout.bridgehead: Weakness and low tone below the level of the lesion
callout.para: The symptoms and signs in spinal cord lesions can be predicted from the anatomy. Important factors to consider are:

listitem.para: The spinal level.
The site in the spine – before or after the last cell body will determine if it is an upper or lower motor neurone sign.
Whether it is affecting the whole cross-section of the cord or only a part of it.
The underlying cause – in this case we are thinking about spina bifida. Acute injuries to the spine such as trauma present with features of spinal shock.

callout.para: There can be orthopaedic complications as a longer term consequence including hip dysplasia and talipes. It is helpful to warn families about these so they do not feel it is their fault.
Sexual dysfunction can be common in young people with spina bifida. It can affect their relationships, sex lives and fertility.
Early referral to appropriate experts in sexual health including urology and gynaecology can be discussed with young people, based on their individual needs and choices.

Pressure sores can bechallenging and are best prevented. It is important to treat early and involve tissue viability experts about management. Pressures sores are more likely if the young person is obese or has a spinal curvature as this increases specific areas of pressure on the skin. For this group other skin problems include latex allergy from repeated exposure are common and it is advisable for these children to avoid all latex products from birth.

tip.para: Lift or shift bottom from chair every 20 minutes and change position of legs at the same time. Check skin all over at least once a day (twice is better). If wet or soiled, the quicker the clean up and change, the better.
Wheelchair users should take care with transfers to avoid skin damage.

chapter.title: John's life story - post birth
chapter.para: John’s defect was successfully closed and the wound has healed well. He had hydrocephalus and a VP shunt was inserted at the time of spinal surgery and his head circumference has stabilised on the 98th percentile. He has established feeding well. He has normal tone and movement in his arms but his legs are flaccid and held in a frog posture. In supine he is able to flex his hips. He does not respond to light pin prick below his knees. He has absent knee, ankle and plantar reflexes. There is no anocutaneous reflex. His anus appears normal and his bowels are opened twice a day. He has bilateral positional talipes .

Monitor urinary tract – John should be followed up in a spina bifida clinic or urology clinic. Encourage the families to continue with clean intermittent catherization. The frequency of this will be determined by follow up investigations looking at John’s bladder. When seeing children with spina bifida, it is important to encourage good fluid intake, monitor their growth, blood pressure and urinalysis. The best guide to the frequency for clean intermittent catheterisation is renal ultrasound that should be repeated at three and six months and then yearly. If there is dilatation of the upper tracts or a residual volume of more than 30 ml, then a discussion with the urology team would be needed. chapter.title: Clinical approach
chapter.para: Clearly there is need to approach this as with any other child with an intercurrent illness but specific factors to consider in the recent history:

listitem.para: VP shunt – Are there any signs of raised intracranial pressure such as headache, vomiting, new or different seizure activity, irritability or drowsiness?
UTI – Is there a history of fever, recent fluid intake, decreased frequency of clean intermittent catherization and any difficulties? Any recent history of constipation?
Fracture – Remember that fractures below the level of the injury will be painless but could there could be abnormal limb positioning or movement.
Medications – particularly any started recently.

chapter.title: Shunt problems: red flags
chapter.para: Children with blocked shunts can deteriorate quickly. It is important to involve a consultant paediatrician early and liaise with neurosurgical team.
For a child with a VP shunt, the first question is: could this be blocked or infected?

note.para: Adapted from West Yorkshire clinical network algorithm.

chapter.para: The second question is: Could this be a UTI? Urinalysis should help and, if this shows nitrites and leucocytes, then it is important that a catheter sample is sent to the lab for MC+S, and appropriate antibiotics started. Provided there have been no recent infections this should be trimethoprim, but it is important to check if there has been any recent urine samples that have been tested as there may be antibiotic resistance.
It important to remember the children with spina bifida will have the same rate of other illnesses as typically developing peers.

chapter.title: Mental health – Self-esteem
chapter.para: We are all affected by self esteem, and this can be more an issue for children with a disability who may see themselves as different. For children, self-esteem comes from:

listitem.para: knowing that they’re loved and that they belong to a family and a community that values them;
spending quality time with their families;
being encouraged to try new things, finding things they’re good at and being praised for things that are important to them.

tip.title: Top tips on how parents can help children with their self esteem

listitem.para: Tell your child you love them; say if often and for no reason other than to show you appreciate them.
Try to have family rituals for example how you say good bye or good night that make your children feel special.
Try to have 10 minutes of one to one time with your child in an activity they enjoy every day.
Encourage friendships with playdates. Have an activity to share if they are struggling to play together such as playdough or den building.
Praise your child, but be specific, e.g well done, that’s a good picture, you knew that that was red.
Put up their pictures on the fridge!

chapter.title: John’s life story – Transition
chapter.para: John is aged 16 years and is progressing well in mainstream high school. He has moved on from wheelchair tennis to wheelchair basket ball and is playing at county level. He is struggling with how he sees himself as different to his typically developing peers and in particular he would like to have a girlfriend he could take to the school prom.
You are now going to see John in clinic. Think about what additional information you would need from that consultation and complete the consultation proforma.

uqf:statement.para: Can sit unaided with c shaped spine, but sits well in supported seating. Independent for transfersAble manual wheelchair userGood hand skills Able communicatorFeed himselfStill needs help with underpants and trousersSocially continent

John is delighted with mitroffanof and is catheterising 3 hourly, and has had no more UTIs, BP and renal u/s normalBowels fine with anal irrigation – no accidentsMood is low and self harmed on at least 2 occasions. Sees himself as different. Wants a girlfriend but thinks this will not happen. Good hearing Myopia unchanged – fed up of glasses

Both of John’s parents are working full time. They are worried that he is becoming increasingly withdrawn and his sleep and eating has deteriorated. When at home he is spending increasing time in his bedroom online.

John had been doing well at school but recently his school performance has declined, but he should still have good GCSE passes. He is planning to stay on at 6th form at his school although it doesn’t offer the subjects he wants as he knows the staff and does not want to take on the challenge of a new college.Has group of friends both high school peers and from basketball team but needs parents help with transport – would like to go to wheelchair basketball summer school but issues around funding Good with time, money and managing technologyDifficulties with cooking because of kitchen layout

chapter.title: Transition: 14 to 18 years
chapter.para: During transition the following issues need to be addressed:

listitem.para: Does he understand about what spina bifida is and how he can look after himself and can he identify where he needs additional support to lead a healthy life?
Does he understand about VP shunts, how to recognize if there are problems and how to seek help?
Does he understand about why he has bladder and bowel difficulties and why it is important to manage these well?
Does he understand about how to look after his skin?
Does he know how to get his medications, and supplies – e.g. catheters?
Does he know who will help if he has a problem with his wheelchair?
Does he know who to contact if there are problems?
Is he aware of the Importance of exercise and a healthy diet?
Is he aware of risk from drugs, alcohol, and smoking?
Is he aware of implications for sexual health and to know how to access help if needed?
Continue to monitor his growth, blood pressure and urinalysis and result of annual ultrasound transfer to adult urology. Also check if he knows how to get their own catheters and gel.
Is he happy with his bowel management? In the case of John – anal irrigation – and does he know how to get supplies of equipment?
Does he have additional support around his toilet, as this will need to be replicated when he moves on to university?
Ensure access to appropriate chair with easy transfer into car.

Ensure there are appropriate adaption for home, school and out of school activities to allow John to join in. This support needs to be mirrored when moving to university. Universities have disabled friendly accommodation on site.

itemizedlist.title: Monitor spine and range of movement at affected joints

listitem.para: If John has a scoliosis, there is a risk of progression during the pubertal growth spurt. Referral to the spinal orthopaedic surgical team is recommended as soon as scoliosis is first identified
John’s energy needs will be different to a mobile peer as his level of activity will be different. Input from dietetic team should be considered if weight is a concern.
It is important to encourage age appropriate independence including:
Self-care feeding, toileting and hygiene needs.
Life skills – being able to use a mobile phone, being on time, managing money including a bank account.
Home skills – to be able to prepare and later plan meals, help with the dishes and laundry.
Travel skills – to encourage independence in the local area including public transport
Make the young person aware they can apply for a driving licence from the age of 16 years, and where they can access an OT assessment to identify the adaptions needed for driving.
Managing health needs – to start to lead the conversation at appointments.
Understand about their ability to access benefits.
Ask about unwelcome comments and bullying. Is the young person feel that if this is an issue they are being supported, and if not find someone who can!
Can they manage emotions such as anger and anxiety. Many schools have support programs in place to help young people handle emotions.
Do they have someone the feel they can talk to, and if not discuss the options and encourage school or family to commit to this support.
Ask about how he feels about the way he looks.

Ask about friends out of school and how easy is it to see them. Look at strategies to be able to do this without direct parental support. If an adult support is needed then encourage the family to engage with social care disability team to look for funding to enable support from a personal assistant.

If an Education, Health and Care plan is in place, this will be reviewed annually and can continue to 25 years of age. What is most important is that the young person’s needs continue to be appropriately met, with staff trained, equipment and environmental adjustments in place, including proactive planning for changes in setting, such as to college, University, apprenticeship or the workplace, linking with the relevant Disability Officer.
Moving to university or college has similar challenges including building in the appropriate support to enable independent living.
Encourage the young person to be involved with work experience and voluntary work to build up their CV.
At the age of 16 years DLA will become PIPs (Personal Independence Payments) which are paid to the young person.
Encourage independence from the family with the help of support workers funded by social care if needed.

chapter.title: Low-mood assessment
chapter.para: When thinking about low mood, the following approach can help you to understand and assess the situation.

listitem.para: All of our moods are affected by life events and it is important to understand what has been going on. In particular think about bereavement, divorce or a severely disappointing experience.

para.emphasis: Could this be depression? Also think about how much it is impacting on the child’s life. The big three:

listitem.para: Persistent low mood or irritability with parents or peers; or
lack of energy affecting their ability to join in life – both friendships and school life; or
lack of enjoyment (anhedonia) – have they altered their activities and engagement.
Poor concentration and difficulties with short term memory – Is there an associated deterioration in school work?
Poor motivation, loss of interest
Poor self esteem/confidence
Somatic symptoms:
Poor sleep – early morning wakening
Poor appetite / weight loss
Loss of libido
Psychomotor retardation/agitation

para.emphasis: Ask about self harm, and if the child is thinking about death or suicide.
Consider other factors with a risk profile:

listitem.para: Previous history of moderate or severe depression
Family discord
Bullying
Sexual or emotional abuse
Drug or alcohol misuse
Parental depression
Homelessness
Refugee status
Living in an institution

chapter.title: Management of low mood
chapter.para: Once you have assessed the situation, the first question is: Does this young person have a significant depression? And in particular: Are there any concerns about suicidal intent?
Depression is defined by DSM (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of mental disorders) version 5 as summarised in the box below.

tip.title: Summarised DSM V Criteria for Major depression
tip.para: A depressed mood, for most of the day and nearly every day; or a loss of interest or pleasure in all or almost all activities nearly every day or fatigue; or loss of energy nearly every day – leading to disengaged from peers, leisure activities and school.

Weight loss or gain of more than 5% Insomnia (especially early morning wakening) or hypersomnia nearly every day Feeling of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt (which may be delusional) nearly every day Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day going on for more than 2 weeks Recurrent thoughts of death (not just fear of dying), recurrent suicidal ideation.

chapter.title: The low mood and depression decision tree
chapter.para: The low mood and depression decision tree (NICE guidance) can help guide your next steps.

chapter.title: Practical strategies for low mood
chapter.para: If you think this is not a major depression and you do no have concerns about significant self-harm and you are taking a watch-and-wait approach, you should offer practical lifestyle advice.

chapter.title: Self harm

tip.title: Red flag
tip.para: Significant suicidal intent is a psychiatric emergency and you need to seek immediate advice

chapter.para: Self harm can take a number of different forms:

listitem.para: Cutting, scratching, carving, branding or marking the body
Picking at scabs so they don’t heal
Pulling hair
Burning or grazing
Biting, bruising due to hitting themselves
Binge drinking, taking a lot of drugs, having unsafe sex or starving themselves

chapter.para: Digital self-harm or self-cyberbullying is when teenagers create alternative online identities for themselves on social media sites and post cruel comments about themselves. The alternative identities might also get cruel comments from other people.

listitem.para: Be calm.
I noticed the cuts / scars on your arm. I hope it’s OK to say that. I would like to help and then offer first aid if needed.
I know that young people only do this when they have really strong emotions and feel very upset. Can you tell me about his?
If they cannot ask if they have someone they feel they can talk to when the time is right so that so they work something out together.
Offer advice leaflet with websites and other self help strategies.

chapter.title: Spina bifida and sexual health
chapter.para: Remember sexuality is not just intercourse and it is important for couples to understand how to physically enjoy each other, e.g. verbal expressions, music, caressing, massage.

listitem.para: Encourage young people to empty bowels and bladder prior to sex to avoid embarrassing accidents.
For girls, fertility is not compromised and contraception remains important.
As for all adults sexually transmitted infections are an issue and therefore encourage latex-free condom use.
General practitioners have good knowledge about contraception and also sexually transmitted infections.

Spinal lesions can affect sensation, the ability to achieve an erection and the experience of an orgasm. If young people are having sexual health difficulties then they should be referred to experts in sexual health, such as the sexual health clinic, urology or gynaecology.

Appropriate support will enhance mobility, enable participation and enhance the quality of life.
